transcripts.text: Right now, let's turn our attention to Liberal Democrat and Foreign Affairs Spokesman, Liberal Democrat MP, Chuka Umunna.  Good morning to you.
Morning, Julie.  Good morning.

Very well indeed.  Well, of course, we've seen all the latest polls that are showing, say that apparently, you know, a Corbyn bounce.  We've seen the damage to the Tory party as a result of the Brexit party announcing that they're going to stand in 600 of the 650 seats unless Boris Johnson tears up his withdrawal agreement, spitting that leave vote.  Things are looking good for the Liberal Democrats, aren't they?

Well, we go into this general election with our strongest, foundations and the strongest set of election results we've had probably since the party was created in 1988.  So we're bullish.  We're confident.  We've got a very clear, distinct position on Brexit.  As you know, you and I talk about it all the time when I come on your show.  We want to stop Brexit altogether, which is not the case with the two main parties.  But I think one thing we can all agree on, regardless of where your allegiance is, whether you're a Leave or remain voter, is that you're a brave person if you try and make predictions about what will happen on December the 12th, because we've still got a long four to five weeks to go of this campaign.  And if the last general election taught us anything, it's that general elections don't always go the way that you think they would.

I think we're in uncharted territory.  We can absolutely all agree on that.  Now, it does appear, though, that the Remain vote is going to be split between Labour and the Liberal Democrats.  And as I say, Jeremy Corbyn getting a bit of a pole bounce, that might be bad for you.  Of course, your party's been looking at doing a pact.  over about 60 different seats to repeat the success you had in the Brecon by-election, which, when the Leave vote was split between the Tories and a much smaller vote going to the Brexit Party, led to you winning that seat.  So doing a deal with the Green Party implied.  I would imagine, other than maybe a couple of seats there, that's basically going to benefit the Liberal Democrat Party, isn't it?

Well, ultimately... We are, you know, it did work in Brecon and Radnorshire.  I think the first thing to say is, I mean, the Liberal Democrats and the other parties involved, the Greens and Plaid, are not like kind of top-down organisations in the way that, say, Labour and the Tories are.  I obviously know the Labour Party quite well, haven't been a member of it for 20 years.  So these things can only work if you get buy-in from local parties where appropriate.  And, I mean, we've always been clear stopping Brexit is the number one priority.  It comes before absolutely everything else.  And so where it's appropriate to do these kinds of arrangements, we're open to considering it.  But as I said, the local party has a huge say in it.  But we've shown in Brecon and Radnorshire that sometimes where you do these things, it can work.  One thing I would just say, I mean, in terms of the Remain vote, I mean, in the end, the parties involved are parties that are committed to stopping Brexit.  Jeremy Corbyn's not committed to stopping Brexit, although I know lots of people in the Labour Party do want that to happen.
But essentially, you talk about, you know, your main policy is stopping Brexit.  It does...
Well, hang on.  I said the... Just to be clear about that, I did say the main priority...
The main priority.  I understand.  I understand.  Apologies.

But I genuinely... ...with dealing with the real issues in this country.  Because I look at the problems in the constituency I represent at the moment.  you know, knife crime, overcrowded housing, an NHS that's underfunded, Brexit and the complete consumption it has taken up of the political bandwidth has stopped us being able to actually deal with those issues.

Yeah, but hold on a minute, Chuka, but this is the thing, isn't it?  It's actually, I don't, genuinely, I don't know, and I'm a political journalist, I don't know any other policies that the Liberal Democrats have, because all that we ever talk about with the Liberal Democrats, and all the Liberal Democrats ever choose to talk about, is stopping Brexit.  Given that realistically, I mean, again, let's not make predictions about what happens on December the 12th, but I think one thing we can say would be unlikely is would be that we have a Liberal Democrat government, a majority government, and therefore revoking of Article 50.  If you did have balance of power in the next election, as a result of the next election, and we ended up having a second referendum, we'd still be talking about Brexit in about a year's time, and more than a year's time, in which case the issues like knife crime, like the NHS and things, would still be on the back burner.

Well, first of all, I'm not going to dispute the fact that we'll still be talking about Brexit this time next year.  We'll probably still be talking about it this time in five years, regardless of what actually happens.  So I don't disagree with you on that, Julia.  But I think the point is, is that you need a resolution of the whole issue.  What we're proposing will actually resolve that issue.  And look, you know, fair cop.  I mean, I don't accept that the party doesn't stand for anything other than stopping Brexit.  I'll tell you something I've discovered since joining the Liberal Democrats is, my gosh, the party loves policy.  And you're going to come across a huge amount of it through this campaign.  We're making a number of announcements this week alone on what our future plans are.  So watch this based on that.  And I'd be very happy to come and talk to you about our plans for the NHS, housing, how we deal with the climate emergency.

We're happy to hear from all parties.  Let's talk about something that the Liberal Democrats won't be part of.  And this is this very first leaders debate on ITV on the 19th of November.  Jo Swinson yesterday basically accused the ITV and Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson of basically a sexist stitch up in not allowing her as part of the leadership debates.  Is that really playing the woman card on this issue?  Is that really fair?
I think it's absolutely fair.  I think it is discriminatory.  I think it is undemocratic.  And I think it is wrong.  The first thing to say is, I mean, obviously, she is the only woman leader.
Why is her possession of European tubes relevant, whether she should be in a leaders debate?

If you just let me finish.  She's the only one of the three main parties, obviously, who is a woman.  And two blokes have decided that they wish to exclude her from a debate.  Now, in 2010, we had similar poll ratings and similar electoral performance going into that debate, and the party leaders and the broadcasters agreed that it should be a three-way affair.  The only difference between then and now is that we have a woman leader now, and there was a male leader then.  That's the first thing.  The second thing is, if you look at the actual Ofcom rules, and you'll be very familiar with this because you're very good at paying attention to them at Talk Radio, it's clear that when you're in an election period, we're about to enter the regulated period at midnight tomorrow.  You have to have due regard and give proportionate cover to the different to the main political parties based on their current electoral performance.  And you should also make sure there's a range of views based on our electoral performance this year in the national election for the first time in 100 years.  We beat both Labour and the Tories.  And of course, as I just said, Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn do not want to stop Brexit.  Of course, that's the biggest political issue of the day.

We do.  No, but hold on.  You've made a number of claims there.  You're saying similar poll ratings to what happened in 2010.  Everyone had this big issue about Nick Clegg joining the three-way debate ahead of the 2010 elections with Gordon Brown and David Cameron.  Ahead of that election, the Liberal Democrats had 62 MPs.  They'd won 22% of the vote.  They went on to win 57 MPs on 23% of the vote.  You currently have 20 MPs.  Eight of them are like you, MPs who weren't elected as Liberal Democrats, and you're only on 14% of the vote.  In no way can you claim to be in a similar position as you were ahead of the 2010 general election.
Actually, I'd say we're in a better position.
You just said you were in the same position.  So which is it, same or better?
Well, I'd argue...
You're in a better position with fewer MPs and a lower predicted share of the vote.

Yes, but this is... How does that work?  I'll explain how it works.  If you go purely on 2017 results as if somehow people's opinions were frozen in aspect at that time and they still exist now, then you might be able to make the argument that you're making.  But if you actually look at the election results this year.  As I said, Labour and the Tories got 23.2% of the vote combined in the national elections we had in May.  We got 20% of the vote.  In the English local elections, we put on over 700 councils, took control of six councils.  Labour and the Tories, between them, lost over 1,400 councillors and they lost control of 50 councils as well.  We're polling in the range of what we scored in the local and European elections.  That is higher than the average poll rating going into the 2010 election.  And of course, as I said, the Ofcom rules require you to have due regard to the range.

Yeah, but it's due regard to the rating, recent elections, and it's a balance gap.  But the reality is, no political party has ever, and we are in uncharted territory, but no political party has ever gone from 20 MPs to 320 odd MPs in one election.  But under... That would be nothing in the polls to suggest that you'll do that.  No one... No, no, no.  Your shadow cabinet meetings, don't tell me you're sitting there going, yeah, so when Joe Swinson is prime minister... I mean, let's be realistic about this.  Your party, you may well hold the balance of power after the next election if there is a hung parliament.  But the TV leadership debate between prospective prime ministers, that can only be between people who will be prime minister as opposed to someone who might... Joe Swinson isn't going to be the next prime minister, is she?

But that is just wrong.  That is a misunderstanding of the Ofcom rules.  And as you just said, you just said, well, look, you may well hold the balance of power.  I'd say that in and of itself is an argument.  to have the leader of the Liberal Democrat in the debate.

But has any of this got anything to do with her being a woman?  Because I've never heard Joe Swinson, I've never heard Sturgeon, Nicola Sturgeon or Theresa May ever play the woman card the way Joe Swinson does.
Nicola, I believe she has actually.  And the last time that there was a dispute around this, the SNP threatened to injunct the broadcaster concerned.
But it wasn't because Nicola Sturgeon was a woman.

It was part of the argument that the SNP made at the time.  I forget which election it was.  I can't remember if it was 2015 or 2017.  Forgive me.  It was definitely part of the argument.  But lawfully, you have to give due regard, as I said, to current and immediate past electoral performance of the parties under the Ofcom rules.  And secondly, most importantly, too, You have to have regard to the range of views.  And if you've got two leaders who do not want to stop Brexit in a debate where we know at least a third of the nation wants to abandon Brexit altogether, clearly what they are doing there is unlawful.
